name: nytimes
text:
RT @NickAtNews: We dove deep into Cup Foods, the deli where the police killed George Floyd.

We learned that in the '90s, the Minneapolis Police Department surveilled the store, conducted undercover drug buys nearby and urged employees to call 911 on loiterers. 
https://t.co/PS27tswbUO

text:
RT @tminsberg: Brown would be shutting down their men's varsity running programs, an email announced. 

12 days later the decision was reversed. 

@alanblinder and I looked into the effort – one that rivals some campaigns for public office – that saved the programs:

name: nytimes
text:
RT @viaSimonRomero: Our updated story on the terrifying scene in Albuquerque tonight when gunfire broke out at protest over Oñate statue

I heard the shots & was in the crowd when mayhem erupted. Still unclear who fired gun & who got shot. It was chaotic  

More:  
 
https://t.co/dIUmag8y5n

name: nytimes
text: A man was shot during a protest Monday night in Albuquerque. Police took into custody several members of a right-wing militia called the New Mexico Civil Guard who were carrying rifles. It was not clear whether any of them had fired the shot. https://t.co/ldhx1bcm8W

name: nytimes
text: After declaring the coronavirus pandemic eradicated last week, New Zealand authorities on Tuesday confirmed 2 new cases of Covid-19 in travelers who had returned from Britain, ending the country’s 24-day streak without new infections https://t.co/2K0FbKE0Mm https://t.co/wjH8GTlARh

text: China's more than 12,000 cinemas have remained stubbornly closed. Reopening them is politically difficult, as the order to keep them shut came from none other than Xi Jinping, China’s top leader. https://t.co/etFU6V6dNX

name: nytimes
text: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, we take you to Gujarat, a state in western India. https://t.co/OO2Gxi9HTi

text: On June 15 and 16, a tentative welcome mat is being laid out for visitors in many European countries and a few Caribbean islands. In most places, Americans won’t be on the invite list. https://t.co/zS4Lz6XRKk

text: “Horrible Histories” is, technically, the only West End show still standing after the coronavirus closed all of London’s theaters in March. The show is still happening, just in a castle parking lot 200 miles away. https://t.co/pYZPZfUSne

text: In 2 weeks, an idea from West Dakota, a drag queen in Brooklyn, blossomed into one of the most striking demonstrations that New York has seen since the killing of George Floyd. Thousands of people gathered in a sea of white. https://t.co/alG6RYBuzl

text: Europe’s internal borders, closed 3 months ago in a frenzy of panicked uncertainty, are opening again, even as politicians and scientists warn that new waves of coronavirus infection might be on the way. https://t.co/IaZzeZrpBN

name: nytimes
text: Public health experts have warned that Africa could become the next epicenter of the Covid-19 pandemic. The WHO said last week that confirmed cases in Africa had doubled in 18 days to reach 200,000; the first 100,000 took 98 days. https://t.co/KmKOCWXya9

text:

“No words can describe what he meant to me and all who knew and loved him,” she said. https://t.co/KMCvJfWAKr
